info.headline: Flood Watch issued September 15 at 11:55PM AST until further notice by NWS San Juan
info.description: ...FLOOD WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY EVENING THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall associated with the passage of Fiona * WHERE...Portions of Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands. * WHEN...From Friday evening through Monday afternoon. * IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations, as well as mudslides and rockfalls in areas of steep terrain. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Fiona is now located 335 miles east-southeast of the Leeward Islands and is expected to arrive Saturday. However, showers and thunderstorms associated with Tropical Storm Fiona are forecast to reach Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as early as Friday Night. These showers and thunderstorms will continue to affect the local islands through at least Monday, increasing the risk for flash flooding across most of the forecast area. Soils are already saturated across areas of higher terrain and, as a result, mudslides and rockfalls are possible as well. - Based on the most recent guidance, the most likely time period for the heaviest rainfall activity is between Saturday and Sunday, the areas most likely to receive the highest rainfall accumulations are portions of southeastern Puerto Rico, where there is a potential for rainfall totals to reach 6 to 8 inches with locally higher amounts around 10 inches. The U.S. Virgin Islands, southern and eastern Puerto Rico has the potential to observe rainfall totals between 4 and 6 inches. Elsewhere, expect rainfall totals to range between 2 and 4 inches. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.
